page.title: 10 Treworgey Manor
page.content: Treworgey Manor is the home of Major Hall, the Lord High Sheriff of Cornwall, and his wife. The manor has 70 acres of land. The original manor house was built in reign of Henry VIII and has been in the possession of the Cannocks and the Hanhaus since then. The manor house was burnt down in 1938 and a new one has been built on the same site. It is thought that there might have been an even older manor house there. In the manor grounds there is a clock tower which was built in 1720. The bell was made in 1620. The clock is a twelve_hour clock, and has only one hand, with four divisions between every hour. It has to be wound up every day. In the stable block there is a room with no windows or doors and which can only be reached by a trapdoor in the ceiling, and which might have been used as a dungeon.
